title: 107_s1733
content: The Act titled "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" establishes an interoperable law enforcement and intelligence data system with name matching capacity and training. The Act "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" mandates the development of a unified electronic data system by key government agencies to access relevant information for visa issuance and alien admissibility. The unified electronic data system required by the Act must have the capacity to match names across different databases, be searchable based on language, provide user support, involve private sector firms in development, and use commercially available platforms. The unified electronic database must be searchable using linguistically sensitive algorithms that account for variations in name formats and transliterations. It should also be adjusted and improved continuously based on experience with the databases and advancements in technologies and sciences. Linguistically sensitive algorithms must account for variations in name formats and transliterations, incorporating advanced linguistic, mathematical, statistical, and anthropological research methods. These algorithms should be developed for at least 4 high-priority languages designated by the Secretary of State and the Attorney General. The unified electronic data system must provide easily accessible information on names in different languages and a means for users to communicate with experts. Interim reports are required to be submitted within 6 months. Interim reports are required to be submitted within 6 months by key government officials. The Director of Central Intelligence must complete a survey and issue a report within a specified timeframe. Additionally, guidelines must be issued and submitted within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. Year 1998 authorizes necessary appropriations for the data system development. Consultation is required with various government agencies and entities in the implementation process. The data system developed under this subsection must adhere to a technology standard established by the United and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism Act of 2001. Information in the system shall be easily accessible to Foreign Service officers issuing visas and Federal agents responsible for determinations. The Secretary of State, the Attorney General, and the Director of Central Intelligence will establish procedures to restrict access to intelligence information in the data system under certain circumstances.
